slides.title: Introduction to Child Nutrition
slides.content:
**Why Nutrition Matters for Children**

Proper nutrition in early childhood (0-6 years) is crucial for:
- Physical growth
- Brain development
- Strong immunity
- Disease prevention
- Lifelong health

**Your Role:**
- Provide supplementary nutrition at Anganwadi
- Educate mothers about nutrition
- Monitor children's nutritional status
- Identify and refer malnourished children

slides.title: Breastfeeding - Exclusive
slides.content:
**Exclusive Breastfeeding (0-6 months)**

**What is Exclusive Breastfeeding?**
- ONLY mother's milk
- No water, no other food
- For first 6 months of life

**Benefits for Baby:**
- Complete nutrition
- Protects from infections
- Easy to digest
- Helps brain development
- Reduces risk of allergies

**Benefits for Mother:**
- Helps uterus return to normal size
- Reduces postpartum bleeding
- Delays next pregnancy (natural spacing)
- Reduces risk of breast and ovarian cancer

**First Yellow Milk (Colostrum):**
- First milk in 2-3 days after birth
- Rich in antibodies
- Protects baby
- Must be given - do not discard!

**Key Message:** No water needed, even in summer!

slides.title: Complementary Feeding
slides.content:
**Starting Solid Foods (6 months onwards)**

**Why Start at 6 Months?**
- Baby needs more nutrition
- Digestive system ready
- Learns to chew

**Continue breastfeeding till 2 years or beyond!**

**First Foods (6 months):**
- Mashed banana
- Rice porridge (khichdi)
- Mashed potato
- Dal water
- Start with 2-3 spoons, gradually increase

**7-9 Months:**
- Mashed foods
- 2-3 meals per day
- Add variety: vegetables, fruits, pulses

**9-12 Months:**
- Finely chopped family foods
- 3-4 meals + snacks
- Finger foods

**12-24 Months:**
- Family foods
- 3 meals + 2 snacks
- Child's own plate

**Important:** Homemade food is best. Avoid junk food.

slides.title: Balanced Diet for Children
slides.content:
**A Balanced Plate for Children**

**Energy Foods (Carbohydrates):**
- Rice, wheat, jowar, bajra
- Bread, roti, idli, dosa
- Potato, sweet potato

**Body-Building Foods (Proteins):**
- Milk and milk products
- Pulses and legumes (dal, rajma, chana)
- Eggs
- Fish, chicken, meat
- Soybean

**Protective Foods (Vitamins & Minerals):**
- **Fruits:** Banana, apple, orange, papaya, mango
- **Green vegetables:** Spinach, fenugreek, amaranth
- **Other vegetables:** Carrot, tomato, pumpkin, beans

**Each Meal Should Have:**
- Cereal (roti/rice)
- Pulse (dal)
- Vegetable
- Little oil/ghee

**Don't Forget:** Water throughout the day!

slides.title: Malnutrition - Types and Signs
slides.content:
**Understanding Malnutrition**

**Protein-Energy Malnutrition:**

**1. Marasmus:**
- Severe weight loss
- Very thin, skeleton-like appearance
- Loose skin folds
- Old man's face
- Alert eyes

**2. Kwashiorkor:**
- Swelling (edema) in feet and hands
- Pot belly
- Skin changes
- Reddish/brownish hair
- Irritable child

**3. Underweight:**
- Weight less than normal for age
- Mild to moderate malnutrition

**Stunting:**
- Height less than normal for age
- Due to chronic malnutrition

**Wasting:**
- Weight less than normal for height
- Due to acute malnutrition

**Action:** Identify using growth chart, refer for treatment.

slides.title: Micronutrient Deficiencies
slides.content:
**Common Vitamin and Mineral Deficiencies**

**Iron Deficiency Anemia:**
- Most common in India
- Symptoms: Pale skin, weakness, tiredness
- Sources: Green leafy vegetables, jaggery, meat, liver
- Give with Vitamin C for better absorption

**Vitamin A Deficiency:**
- Causes: Night blindness, eye problems
- Sources: Carrot, papaya, mango, milk, eggs
- Government gives Vitamin A dose every 6 months

**Iodine Deficiency:**
- Causes: Goiter (swollen neck), mental problems
- Prevention: Use iodized salt only

**Vitamin D Deficiency:**
- Causes: Rickets (bow legs, weak bones)
- Sources: Sunlight (best), milk, fish
- Expose baby to morning sunlight daily

**Zinc Deficiency:**
- Slows growth
- Weakens immunity
- Sources: Pulses, nuts, meat

slides.title: Feeding Sick Children
slides.content:
**Nutrition During Illness**

**Key Principle:** Continue feeding during illness!

**During Diarrhea:**
- Continue breastfeeding
- Give ORS frequently
- Continue regular food (not heavy)
- Avoid fasting
- After recovery: Give extra meal for 2 weeks

**During Fever:**
- Give plenty of fluids
- Soft, easy-to-digest foods
- Small, frequent meals
- Continue breastfeeding

**During Cough/Cold:**
- Warm fluids help
- Continue normal diet
- Avoid cold foods if child refuses

**Important Points:**
- Sick children need MORE nutrition, not less
- Don't restrict diet unnecessarily
- Encourage eating, be patient
- After illness: Give extra food to regain lost weight

slides.title: Growth Monitoring
slides.content:
**Using Growth Charts**

**What is Growth Monitoring?**
- Regular measurement of weight and height
- Plotting on growth chart
- Tracking child's growth pattern

**How to Measure:**

**Weight:**
- Weigh monthly for children 0-2 years
- Weigh every 3 months for children 2-6 years
- Use baby weighing scale for infants
- Record in growth chart

**Height:**
- Measure every 3-6 months
- Use measuring board/scale

**Interpreting Growth Chart:**
- **Green Zone:** Normal growth
- **Yellow Zone:** At risk, needs attention
- **Red Zone:** Malnourished, refer immediately

**If weight not increasing:**
- Check feeding practices
- Check for illness
- Counsel mother
- Refer if needed

**Regular monitoring helps detect problems early!**

slides.title: Anganwadi Supplementary Nutrition
slides.content:
**Supplementary Nutrition Programme (SNP)**

**Who Gets Supplementary Food?**
- Children 6 months to 6 years
- Pregnant women
- Lactating mothers

**What is Provided?**

**For Children 6 months - 3 years:**
- Take-home ration
- Ready-to-eat food packets
- Energy: 500 kcal/day
- Protein: 12-15 grams/day

**For Children 3-6 years:**
- Hot cooked meal at Anganwadi
- Energy: 500 kcal/day
- Protein: 12-15 grams/day

**For Pregnant & Lactating Women:**
- Take-home ration
- Energy: 600 kcal/day
- Protein: 18-20 grams/day

**Your Responsibility:**
- Prepare hygienic food
- Ensure all eligible children get food
- Maintain attendance register
- Check quality of food

question.questionText: For how many months should a baby be exclusively breastfed?
question.explanation: Exclusive breastfeeding means giving ONLY mother's milk (no water, no other food) for the first 6 months of life. After 6 months, complementary foods should be started while continuing breastfeeding till 2 years or beyond.
